function l_sort(col,coltype,hier,hiercol,mach,colname,sAlternateSortType)153{154 // this is used in cases where a column needs to be sorted by something different than itâ€™s type/value155 if(sAlternâ€¦

function l_sort(col,coltype,hier,hiercol,mach,colname,sAlternateSortType)

153{

154 // this is used in cases where a column needs to be sorted by something different than itâ€™s type/value

155 if(sAlternateSortType != null)

156 coltype = sAlternateSortType;

157 var i = 0, node,node2, numRows = 0, rnode, col2 = -1, col2type;

158 var elems = new Array(), elem, cols;

159 var dir_up = true, dir_up2;

160 var ordered_mach = false;

161 if (mach == â€˜â€™ || mach == null) mach = â€˜â€™;

162 else if (document.forms[0].elements[mach+â€™sortidxâ€™] != null)

163 {

164 col2 = document.forms[0].elements[mach+â€™sortidxâ€™].value;

165 if (col2 == col)

166 col2 = -1;

167 else

168 {

169 col2type = document.forms[0].elements[mach+â€™sorttypeâ€™].value;

170 dir_up2 = document.forms[0].elements[mach+â€™sortdirâ€™].value == â€œUPâ€;

171 }

172 ordered_mach = hasEncodedField(mach,mach+â€seqnumâ€);

173 }

174

175 node = l_id(mach+â€™dirâ€™+col);

176 if (node.src.indexOf(â€˜nlup.gifâ€™) != -1)

177 dir_up = false;

178 node.src = dir_up ? â€˜/images/nav/nlup.gifâ€™ : â€˜/images/nav/nldown.gifâ€™;

179 node2 = l_id(mach+â€™headerâ€™);

180 for (idx=0; idx < node2.cells.length; idx++)

181 {

182 if (idx == col)

183 continue;

184 node = l_id(mach+â€™dirâ€™+idx);

185 if (node != undefined)

186 node.src = â€˜/images/nav/nlempty.gifâ€™;

187 }

188

189 while (true)

190 {

191 node = l_id(mach+â€™rowâ€™+i);

192 if (node != undefined)

193 {

194 // when we are sorting by a different type/value than the cell contiains, that value will

195 // exist in a hidden span - which will always be the first child within the

196 if(sAlternateSortType != null)

197 elem = node.cells[col].firstChild.innerHTML;

198 else

199 elem = node.cells[col].innerHTML;

200 cols = new Array();

201

202 for (idx=0; idx < node.cells.length; idx++)

203 {

204 cols[idx] = node.cells[idx].innerHTML;

205

206 if(node.cells[idx].firstChild && node.cells[idx].firstChild.nodeName == â€˜INPUTâ€™ && node.cells[idx].firstChild.type == â€˜checkboxâ€™)

207 {

208 // If a checkbox is checked now, but was not checked the last time we drew it, add CHECKED to the input tag

209 if(node.cells[idx].firstChild.checked && node.cells[idx].innerHTML.indexOf(â€˜checkedâ€™) < 0)

210 cols[idx] = cols[idx].substring(0,cols[idx].length-1) + â€˜ CHECKED>â€™;

211 // else if a checkbox is NOT checked, but it was when we drew it, remove CHECKED from the input tag

212 else if(!node.cells[idx].firstChild.checked && node.cells[idx].innerHTML.indexOf(â€˜checkedâ€™) >= 0)

213 cols[idx] = cols[idx].substring(0,cols[idx].indexOf(â€˜checkedâ€™)) + â€˜>â€™;

214 }

215

216 }

217

218

219 if (hier)

220 {

221 hierfld = l_elem(â€˜_hierâ€™+i);

222 if (hiercol)

223 elem = hierfld.value;

224 elems[i] = new l_node(elem.toLowerCase(),cols,coltype,dir_up,hierfld.value);

225 }

226 else if (col2 != -1)

227 elems[i] = new l_node(elem.toLowerCase(),cols,coltype,dir_up,null,node.cells[col2].innerHTML,col2type,dir_up2, ordered_mach ? findEncodedValue(mach, mach+â€seqnumâ€, i+1) : -1);

228 else

229 elems[i] = new l_node(elem.toLowerCase(),cols,coltype,dir_up,null,null,null,null,ordered_mach ? findEncodedValue(mach, mach+â€seqnumâ€, i+1) : -1);

230 i++;

231 }

232 else

233 break;

234 }

235

236 numRows = i;

237 i = 0;

238

239 elems.sort(l_sortnodes);

240

241 while (i < numRows)

242 {

243 node = l_id(mach+â€™rowâ€™+i);

244 rnode = elems[i];

245 cols = rnode.row;

246

247 for (idx=0; idx < node.cells.length; idx++)

248 node.cells[idx].innerHTML = cols[idx];

249

250 if (hier)

251 {

252 hierfld = l_elem(â€˜_hierâ€™+i);

253 hierfld.value = rnode.hier;

254 }

255 if (ordered_mach)

256 setEncodedValue(mach,rnode.linenum,mach+â€™seqnumâ€™,i+1);

257 i++;

258 }

259 l_saveprefs(mach, col, colname, coltype, dir_up);

260}

261

262function l_sortprefs(col,coltype,mach,colname)

263{

264 var dir_up = true;

265 node = l_id(mach+â€™dirâ€™+col);

266 if (node.src.indexOf(â€˜nlup.gifâ€™) != -1)

267 dir_up = false;

268 l_saveprefs(mach, col, colname, coltype, dir_up);

269}

entry.title: netsuite SyncQtyRate-CarlZeng
entry.content:
function SyncQtyRate()206{207 var form = document.forms[â€˜item_formâ€™];208 // Make sure all the fields are there. Otherwise, bail out.209 if (!(form.elements[â€˜ratescheduleâ€™] && form.elements[â€˜quantityâ€™]â€¦

function SyncQtyRate()

206{

207 var form = document.forms[â€˜item_formâ€™];

208 // Make sure all the fields are there. Otherwise, bail out.

209 if (!(form.elements[â€˜ratescheduleâ€™] && form.elements[â€˜quantityâ€™]))

210 return;

211 // If this line is a credit of some other doc, retain the original QtyRate on the line

212 if ( (form.elements[â€˜orderdocâ€™] && form.elements[â€˜orderdocâ€™].value.length > 0) || (form.elements[â€˜srclineâ€™] && form.elements[â€˜srclineâ€™].value.length > 0) )

213 return;

214 var schedstr = form.elements[â€˜ratescheduleâ€™].value;

215 var qty = parseFloat(form.elements[â€˜quantityâ€™].value);

216 var marginal = â€˜Tâ€™ == form.elements[â€˜marginalâ€™].value;

217 var overallqtydisc = form.elements[â€˜overallqtydiscâ€™].value;

218 if (overallqtydisc.length>0)

219 {

220 var linecount=item_machine.getNextIndex()-1;

221 var linenum=item_machine.getMachineIndex();

222 var qtygroup=parseInt(form.elements[â€˜qtygroupâ€™].value);

223 for (var j=1; j <= linecount; j++)

224 if (j != linenum && getEncodedValue(â€˜itemâ€™,j,â€™overallqtydiscâ€™) == overallqtydisc && parseInt(getEncodedValue(â€˜itemâ€™,j,â€™qtygroupâ€™)) == qtygroup && parseFloat(getEncodedValue(â€˜itemâ€™,j,â€™quantityâ€™))>0) qty += parseFloat(getEncodedValue(â€˜itemâ€™,j,â€™quantityâ€™));

225 }

226 var bCustomPriceLevel = form.elements[â€˜priceâ€™] != null && parseFloat(form.elements[â€˜priceâ€™].value) == -1;

227

228 if (schedstr.length>0 && !isNaN(qty) && !bCustomPriceLevel)

229 {

230 form.elements[â€˜rateâ€™].value=format_rate(round_float(getQtyRate(schedstr,qty,marginal)));

231 fireProperOnChange(form.elements[â€˜rateâ€™]);

232 }

233}

entry.title: netsuite nlapiLineInit-CarlZeng
entry.content:
function nlapiValidateField(type, fld, optionswin, linenum){var isValid = true;if (optionswin != null)optwin = optionswin;if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVF != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elemenâ€¦

function nlapiValidateField(type, fld, optionswin, linenum)
{
var isValid = true;
if (optionswin != null)
optwin = optionswin;
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVF != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVF.value.length > 0)
{
var fldnam = fld.name;
if (linenum != null)
fldnam = fldnam.substring(0,fldnam.length-linenum.toString().length)
else if ( type != null )
linenum = nlapiGetCurrentLineItemIndex(type)
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVF.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; isValid && i < scripts.length; i++ )
{
var checkValidOrig = fld.checkvalid
try
{
fld.checkvalid = false;
isValid = eval( scripts[ i ]+â€(type, fldnam, linenum)â€ );
}
finally
{
fld.checkvalid = checkValidOrig;
}
if (!isValid)
{
if (typeof(ftabs) != â€˜undefinedâ€™)
{
var tab = ftabs[fldnam.toLowerCase()];
if (tab != null && tab != â€œmainâ€ && !isTabShown(tab))
ShowTab(tab,true);
}
setFieldFocus( fld );
if ( fld.select != null ) fld.select();
optwin = null;
}
}
}

optwin = null;
nsapiBuildChangedLineItems();
return isValid;
}
function nlapiFieldChanged(type, fld, optionswin, linenum)
{
var fldnam = fld.name;
if (linenum != null)
fldnam = fldnam.substring(0,fldnam.length-linenum.toString().length)
else if ( type != null )
linenum = nlapiGetCurrentLineItemIndex(type)
if (optionswin != null)
optwin = optionswin;
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiFC != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiFC.value.length > 0)
{
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiFC.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; i < scripts.length; i++ )
eval(scripts[ i ]+â€(type, fldnam, linenum)â€);
}

optwin = null;
nsapiBuildChangedLineItems();
}
function nlapiPostSourcing(type, fldname)
{
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiPS != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiPS.value.length > 0)
{
var origflag = window.isinited;
try
{ /* â€” set inited flags so that machine calls function correctly. */
setIsInited( window, true );
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiPS.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; i < scripts.length; i++ )
eval(scripts[ i ]+â€(type, fldname)â€);
}
finally /* unset page_init flags. */
{
setIsInited( window, origflag );
}
}
}
function nlapiLineInit(type)
{
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiLI != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiLI.value.length > 0)
{
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiLI.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; i < scripts.length; i++ )
eval(scripts[ i ]+â€(type)â€);
}
}
function nlapiValidateLine(type)
{
var isValid = true;
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVL != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVL.value.length > 0)
{
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiVL.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; isValid && i < scripts.length; i++ )
isValid = eval(scripts[ i ]+â€(type)â€);
}
return isValid;
}
function nlapiRecalc(type)
{
if (nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiRC != null && nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiRC.value.length > 0)
{
var scripts = nsapiGetMainForm( ).elements.nlapiRC.value.split(â€˜,â€™);
for ( var i = 0; i < scripts.length; i++ )
eval(scripts[ i ]+â€(type)â€);
}
}

entry.title: Kcptun - A UDP Tunnel Based on KCP Protocol - Converting TCP Streams to KCP+UDP to Stream IPTV
entry.content:
Suited for applications with low latency and high speed requirements, it is reputed to double the transmission efficiency X2+.

Target

Accelerating end-to-end remote transmission (point-to-point p2p transmission, encapsulating TCP data as UDP KCP data) through UDP tunneling.

Kcptun is a simple and fast UDP tunnel based on the KCP protocol, capable of converting TCP streams to KCP+UDP streams.

Application

Simple deployment and configuration.

Hereâ€™s an example:

  1. A certain application on a remote/distant client needs to access a specific TCP service within the serverâ€™s network segment (such as a game or IPTV).
  2. By launching the kcptun client on the remote clientâ€™s router#1 (listening on a local port and then specifying the serverâ€™s IP and port, along with encryption information), this kcptun clientâ€™s listening port becomes the port the local application will use to connect.
  3. Connect to the specific kcp server (listening on the serverâ€™s port and then specifying the destination TCP service [IP address and port]) through the server (forwarded from router#2â€™s port).
  4. This encrypted and encapsulated entire chain is established over UDP, purportedly doubling transmission efficiency X2+.

Below are two examples of using docker for kcptun applications.

Practical Example 1:

https://hub.docker.com/r/lowid/kcptun

If the service to be encapsulated is a SOCKS proxy on the server:

Server side (kcp+socks) compose file

Server side sockd.conf

Client side compose file

Practical Example 2:

Related Content

Implementation Approach

Abandoning the docker approach.

KCP Server:

Explanatory note: Because this service on port 29900 is configured on a specific server (not on the main routerâ€™s public IP), it requires port mapping on the main routerâ€™s public IP (i.e., to forward external 29900 UDP data to the same port on this specific server).

A comprehensive diagram of the entire process

A peculiar testing method was used to play through frp to another location;
Testing experience: High definition is very smooth, 4K still experiences some lag;
TODO: Waiting for the next step to test local area network playback on the client side after KCP transmission.

After such KCP transmission, as per reports, the transmission latency is halved, and the speed is doubled X2+; awaiting further practical testing to verify.

Source of Inspiration

[Tutorial, project address: https://github.com/xtaci/kcptun/](

function ShowHideTab(tname,shown) {
if (document.all[tname+â€™_divâ€™] == null || document.all[tname+â€™_divâ€™].style.visibility == (shown ? â€˜visibleâ€™ : â€˜hiddenâ€™)) return;
document.all[tname+â€™_divâ€™].style.zIndex = shown ? 2 : -1;

var machs = allmachs[tname].split(â€˜,â€™)
var mach = vismachs[tname]
var dotmachs = â€˜â€™;
if (shown) {
var i
for (i=0;i<machs.length;i++) {
var dotmach = machs[i];
if (dotmach != null && dotmach != mach && document.all[dotmach+â€™_layerâ€™] != null && document.forms.main_form.elements[dotmach+â€™dottedâ€™] != null && document.forms.main_form.elements[dotmach+â€™dottedâ€™].value==â€™Fâ€™)
dotmachs += (dotmachs.length > 0 ? String.fromCharCode(5) : â€˜â€™)+dotmach;
} }
if (shown && mach != null && document.all[mach+â€™_layerâ€™].style.visibility != â€˜hiddenâ€™ && document.all[mach+â€™_layerâ€™].style.display != â€˜noneâ€™ && document.forms.main_form.elements[mach+â€™loadedâ€™] != null && document.forms.main_form.elements[mach+â€™loadedâ€™].value==â€™Fâ€™) refreshmachine(mach, null, true, dotmachs.length > 0 ? dotmachs : null );
else if (shown && dotmachs.length > 0) refreshmachine(null, null, true, dotmachs )
document.images[tname+â€™ltiâ€™].src=document.images[tname+â€™ltiâ€™].src.replace(shown ? /_plain/ : /_stroked/,shown ? â€˜_strokedâ€™ : â€˜_plainâ€™);
document.images[tname+â€™rtiâ€™].src=document.images[tname+â€™rtiâ€™].src.replace(shown ? /_plain/ : /_stroked/,shown ? â€˜_strokedâ€™ : â€˜_plainâ€™);

var tabDiv = document.all[tname+â€™_divâ€™]
tabDiv.style.visibility = shown ? â€˜visibleâ€™ : â€˜hiddenâ€™;
tabDiv.style.display = shown ? â€˜blockâ€™ : â€˜noneâ€™;
document.all[tname+â€™ltâ€™].className = shown ? â€˜bgontabbottomâ€™ : â€˜bgofftabbottomâ€™;

if(shown) {
document.forms[â€˜main_formâ€™].elements[â€˜selectedtabâ€™].value = tname;
tabDiv.className = â€˜bgontabbottomâ€™;
if ( mach != null ) sizeLowerTabBGDiv(mach);
}
}

nlapiDateToString(new Date())new Date() å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°å½“å‰æ—¥æœŸ.var cur_time = (new Date()).getTime(); è·å–å½“å‰æ—¶é—´.â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”Example 1The following example uses nlapiTransformRecord to creâ€¦

nlapiDateToString(new Date())

new Date() å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°å½“å‰æ—¥æœŸ.

var cur_time = (new Date()).getTime(); è·å–å½“å‰æ—¶é—´.

-â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“

Example 1

The following example uses nlapiTransformRecord to create an Item Fulfillment record from an existing Sales Order record.

var itemfulfillment = nlapiTransformRecord(â€˜salesorderâ€™, 1500, â€˜itemfulfillmentâ€™)

itemfulfillment.setFieldValue(â€˜trandateâ€™, nlapiDateToString(new Date()) )

Example 2

The next script shows how to create an Item Receipt record from a Purchase Order.

function trans()

{

var fromrecord;

var fromid;

var torecord;

var trecord;

var qty;

fromrecord = â€˜purchaseorderâ€™;

fromid = 26 ; // Transform PO with ID = 26 ;

torecord = â€˜itemreceiptâ€™;

// Transaform a record with given id to a different record type.

// For example - from PO to Item Receipt

// Get the object of the transformed record.

trecord = nlapiTransformRecord(fromrecord, fromid, torecord,true);

qty = trecord.getLineItemValue(â€˜itemâ€™, â€˜quantityâ€™, 1 );

trecord.setLineItemValue(â€˜itemâ€™, â€˜quantityâ€™, 1, â€˜2â€™ );

var idl = nlapiSubmitRecord(trecord, true);

nlapiSendEmail(-5, -5, â€˜Transform Emailâ€™ + â€˜Original Qty =

â€˜ + qty + â€˜ â€˜ + â€˜Record Created = â€˜ + idl , null);

}

Example 3

The following script shows how to create a Build item record from an Assembly record.

/* Assembly item Name = Computer and Id = 328

Location Name = West and Id = 3 // When Multi Location inventory is enabled

2 Member components of Assembly item

Member 1 Name = CPU - Quantity = 2

Member 2 Name = Memory - Quantity = 4

*/

function transformtest1()

{

var fromRecord = â€˜assemblyitemâ€™;

var fromId = 328;

var toRecord = â€˜buildâ€™;

var defaultV = new Array();

defaultV.quantity =1; // Default quantity to build

defaultV.location =â€™3â€™; // Default location id

var record = nlapiTransformRecord(fromRecord, fromId, toRecord, defaultV);

var id = nlapiSubmitRecord(record, false);

}

function setTarget(s,i) {
var frm,fldnam,fld;
frm = parent.opener.document.forms.item_form;
fldnam = â€˜serialnumbersâ€™;
fld = parent.opener.getFormElement(frm,fldnam);

æ‰€æœ‰æ‰¹å·çš„èµ‹å€¼å…³é”®å°±åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªaddMultiSelectValue(fld,i,s);ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¥ç€æ¥çœ‹ï¼š

function addMultiSelectValue(sel, val, name)
{
if (isNLMultiDropDown(sel))
{
var dd = getMultiDropdown(sel);
var idx = dd.getIndexForValue(val);
dd.addIndex(idx);
}
else if (sel.type == â€œselect-multipleâ€)
{
var opts = sel.options;
for (var i=0; i < opts.length; i++)
if ( opts[i].value == val )
opts[i].selected = true;
}
else
{
var values = sel.value.split(String.fromCharCode(5));
for (var i=0;i < values.length;i++)
if (values[i] == val) return;
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_displayâ€].style.color = â€˜000000â€™;
if (values.length == 0 || values[0].length == 0)
{
sel.value = val;
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_displayâ€].value = name;
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_labelsâ€].value = name;
}
else
{
sel.value += String.fromCharCode(5)+val;
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_labelsâ€].value += String.fromCharCode(5)+name;
var lines = sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_displayâ€].value.split(/\n|\r/);
if (lines.length == values.length)
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_displayâ€].value += â€œ\nâ€+name;
else
{
lines[values.length] = name;
sel.form.elements[sel.name+â€_displayâ€].value = lines.join(â€œ\nâ€);
}
}

* @param url URL of request handlerÂ Â  Â 
* @param methodName method name on remote object to callÂ Â  Â 
* @param methodParams an array of parameters to the methodÂ Â  Â 
* @param asyncCallback a callback if this is to be an async request. Callback signature should be: callback(result, error)Â Â  Â 
*/Â Â  Â 
function nlapiServerCall(url, methodName, methodParams, asyncCallback)Â Â  Â 
{Â Â  Â

function nlapiLocalCall(func, timeoutinmillis)Â Â  Â 
{Â Â  Â 
nsapiAssertTrue(timeoutinmillis != null && !isNaN(parseInt(timeoutinmillis)), â€˜SSS_INVALID_ARGUMENTâ€™, â€˜timeoutinmillis: â€˜+timeoutinmillis)Â Â  Â 
var obj = new Object()Â Â  Â 
obj.trigger = nsapiQueryScript(â€œtriggerâ€)Â Â  Â 
obj.scriptid = nsapiQueryScript(â€œscriptidâ€)Â Â  Â 
if ( timeoutinmillis == -1 )Â Â  Â 
return nsapiCallScript(obj.trigger, obj.scriptid, func)Â Â  Â 
return setTimeout( function() { nsapiCallScript(obj.trigger, obj.scriptid, func); }, timeoutinmillis );Â Â  Â

-â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

/**
* @param url URL of request handler
* @param methodName method name on remote object to call
* @param methodParams an array of parameters to the method
* @param asyncCallback a callback if this is to be an async request. Callback signature should be: callback(result, error)
*/
function nsServerCall(url, methodName, methodParams, asyncCallback)
{
var client = new NLJsonRpcClient(url);
return client.sendRequest(methodName, methodParams, asyncCallback);
}

NLJsonRpcClient = function (serverURL)
{
if (serverURL.indexOf(â€œ?â€) > 0)
serverURL = serverURL + â€œ&jrpc=Tâ€;
else
serverURL = serverURL + â€œ?jrpc=Tâ€;
this.serverURL = serverURL;
this.responseCallbackMap = {};
};
NLJsonRpcClient.requestId = 0;
NLJsonRpcClient.prototype =
{
sendRequest : function (methodName, args, callback)
{
var jsonRpcReq = {
id : NLJsonRpcClient.requestId++,
method : â€œremoteObject.â€ + methodName,
params : args || []
};
if (callback != null)
this.responseCallbackMap[jsonRpcReq.id] = callback;
var request = new NLXMLHttpRequest();
if (callback != null)
request.setResponseHandler(this.handleResponseAsync.bindAsEventListener(this));
var response = request.requestURL(this.serverURL, toJSON(jsonRpcReq), null, callback != null ? true : false);
if (callback == null)
{
var jsonRpcResp = this.getJsonRpcResponse(response);
if (jsonRpcResp.error)
throw new NLXMLResponseError(jsonRpcResp.error.code, jsonRpcResp.error.trace, jsonRpcResp.error.msg);
response = jsonRpcResp.result;
}
return response;
}, 

getJsonRpcResponse : function (nlXMLResponseObj)  
{  
    var jsonRpcResp = nlXMLResponseObj.getBody();  
    if (jsonRpcResp != null)  
        jsonRpcResp = jsonRpcResp.replace(/^\\s\*<!--\[\\s\\S\]\*?-->\\s\*$/gm, '');  
    eval("jsonRpcResp = " + jsonRpcResp + ";");  
    return jsonRpcResp;  
},  

handleResponseAsync : function (nlXMLResponseObj)  
{  
    var jsonRpcResp = this.getJsonRpcResponse(nlXMLResponseObj);  
    var callback = this.responseCallbackMap\[jsonRpcResp.id\];  
    this.responseCallbackMap\[jsonRpcResp.id\] = null;  
    callback(jsonRpcResp.result, jsonRpcResp.error);  
}

}

function toJSON(o)
{
if (o == null)
return â€œnullâ€;
else if(o.constructor == String || o.constructor.name == â€œStringâ€)
return escapeJSONString(o);
else if(o.constructor == Number || o.constructor.name == â€œNumberâ€)
return o.toString();
else if(o.constructor == Boolean || o.constructor.name == â€œBooleanâ€)
return o.toString();
else if(o.constructor == Date || o.constructor.name == â€œDateâ€)
return â€˜{javaClass: â€œjava.util.Dateâ€, time: â€˜ + o.valueOf() +â€™}â€™;
else if((o.constructor == Array || o.constructor.name == â€œArrayâ€))
{
var v = [];
for (var i = 0; i < o.length; i++) v.push(toJSON(o[i]));
return â€œ[â€œ + v.join(â€œ, â€œ) + â€œ]â€œ;
}
else
{
var v = [];
for(attr in o)
{
if(o[attr] == null) v.push(â€œ\â€œâ€ + attr + â€œ\â€œ: nullâ€);
else if(typeof o[attr] == â€œfunctionâ€); /* skip */
else v.push(escapeJSONString(attr) + â€œ: â€œ + toJSON(o[attr]));
}
return â€œ{â€œ + v.join(â€œ, â€œ) + â€œ}â€;
}
}

3, â€˜New Jerseyâ€™,
4, â€˜Seattleâ€™,

ä¸‹é¢ä»‹ç»å–å€¼çš„

getSetting(type, name)
Returns a system or script setting
Important: SCRIPT is the only type supported in Client SuiteScript.

Parameters
? type{string}[required] - The type of script/system setting. Possible values include:
? SCRIPT - script parameter (defined per script)
? SESSION - session variable (volatile setting defined per session)
? FEATURE - returns T (enabled) or F (disabled) depending on whether a feature is
enabled. In the SuiteScript Reference Guide, see â€œFeature Names and IDsâ€ o
page 335 for all NetSuite feature names and internal IDs.
? PERMISSION - returns permission level: 0 (none), 1 (view), 2 (create), 3 (edit), 4
(full). In the SuiteScript Reference Guide, see â€œPermission Names and IDsâ€ o
page 327 for all NetSuite permission IDs.
? name {string} [required]- The name of the script/system setting

Important: You must use the nlobContext.getSetting method on nlapiGetContext to reference
script parameters. For example, to obtain the value of a script parameter called
custscript_case_field, you use the following code:
nlapiGetContext().getSetting(â€˜SCRIPTâ€™, â€˜custscript_case_fieldâ€™)

Returns
? If type is specified as SCRIPT, SESSION, or FEATURE, a string value is returned. If
type is specified as PERMISSION, an integer value is returned.

-â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

ä¸‹é¢ä»‹ç»è®¾ç½®å€¼çš„ï¼š

setSetting(type, name, value)
Sets the value of a script or user-defined setting. Only available in Server SuiteScript.
? type{string} [required] - The type of script/system setting
? SESSION - session variable (volatile setting defined per session)
? name{string} [required]- The name of the script/system setting
? value {string} [required]- The new value for the script/system setting
Returns
? void

/* ncBGP_WriteToLog - utility function to write to the Background Process Manager log table
*
* This function will create a new NC Process Log record using the details provided
*
* Parameters:
* ProcessId - the id of the current process record
* RecordRef - a reference for the current record being processed or which the message relates to
* MessageText - the message text to be written to the log
* MessageType - the type of message, â€˜Errorâ€™, â€˜Warningâ€™ or â€˜Messageâ€™
*/
function ncBGP_WriteToLog(ProcessId,RecordRef,MessageText,MessageType)
{
var l_MsgType;
switch (MessageType)
{
case â€˜Errorâ€™:
l_MsgType = 1;
break;

case â€˜Warningâ€™:
l_MsgType = 2;
break;

case â€˜Messageâ€™:
default:
l_MsgType = 3;
}

var LogRec = nlapiCreateRecord(â€˜customrecord_ncbgp_processlogâ€™);
LogRec.setFieldValue(â€˜custrecord_logprocessidâ€™,ProcessId);
LogRec.setFieldValue(â€˜custrecord_logrecordrefâ€™,RecordRef);
LogRec.setFieldValue(â€˜custrecord_logmessagetypeâ€™,l_MsgType);
LogRec.setFieldValue(â€˜custrecord_logmessagedetailâ€™,MessageText);
nlapiSubmitRecord(LogRec,false);
}

å¸Œæœ›å¯¹å¤§å®¶é‡æ–°è®¤è¯† Javascript æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ã€‚ ä»£ç : /** * å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªå…¨å±€å¯¹è±¡, å±æ€§ Version åœ¨å‘å¸ƒçš„æ—¶å€™ä¼šæ›¿æ¢ä¸ºå½“å‰ç‰ˆæœ¬å· */ var Prototype = { Version: â€˜@@VERSION@@â€™ } /** * åˆ›å»ºä¸€ç§ç±»å‹ï¼Œæ³¨æ„å…¶å±æ€§ create æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ„é€ å‡½æ•°ã€‚ * ä¸€èˆ¬ä½¿ç”¨å¦‚ä¸‹ * var X = Classâ€¦

å¸Œæœ›å¯¹å¤§å®¶é‡æ–°è®¤è¯† Javascript æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ã€‚

ä»£ç :

/**
* å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªå…¨å±€å¯¹è±¡, å±æ€§ Version åœ¨å‘å¸ƒçš„æ—¶å€™ä¼šæ›¿æ¢ä¸ºå½“å‰ç‰ˆæœ¬å·
*/
var Prototype = {
Version: â€˜@@VERSION@@â€™

/**
* åˆ›å»ºä¸€ç§ç±»å‹ï¼Œæ³¨æ„å…¶å±æ€§ create æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ„é€ å‡½æ•°ã€‚
* ä¸€èˆ¬ä½¿ç”¨å¦‚ä¸‹
* var X = Class.create(); è¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªç±»å‹ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äº java çš„ä¸€ä¸ªClasså®ä¾‹ã€‚
* è¦ä½¿ç”¨ X ç±»å‹ï¼Œéœ€ç»§ç»­ç”¨ new X()æ¥è·å–ä¸€ä¸ªå®ä¾‹ï¼Œå¦‚åŒ java çš„ Class.newInstance()æ–¹æ³•ã€‚
*
* è¿”å›çš„æ„é€ å‡½æ•°ä¼šæ‰§è¡Œåä¸º initialize çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œ initialize æ˜¯ Ruby å¯¹è±¡çš„æ„é€ å™¨æ–¹æ³•åå­—ã€‚
* æ­¤æ—¶initializeæ–¹æ³•è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å®šä¹‰ï¼Œå…¶åçš„ä»£ç ä¸­åˆ›å»ºæ–°ç±»å‹æ—¶ä¼šå»ºç«‹ç›¸åº”çš„åŒåæ–¹æ³•ã€‚
*
* å¦‚æœä¸€å®šè¦ä»javaä¸Šå»ç†è§£ã€‚ä½ å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºç”¨Class.create()åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªç»§æ‰¿java.lang.Classç±»çš„ç±»ã€‚å½“ç„¶javaä¸å…è®¸è¿™æ ·åšï¼Œå› ä¸ºClassç±»æ˜¯finalçš„
*
*/
var Class = {
create: function() {
return function() {
this.initialize.apply(this, arguments);
}
}
}

/**
* åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡ï¼Œä»å˜é‡åæ¥æ€è€ƒï¼Œæœ¬æ„ä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªæŠ½è±¡ç±»ï¼Œä»¥ååˆ›å»ºæ–°å¯¹è±¡éƒ½ extend å®ƒã€‚
* ä½†ä»å…¶åä»£ç çš„åº”ç”¨æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œ Abstract æ›´å¤šæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†ä¿æŒå‘½åç©ºé—´æ¸…æ™°çš„è€ƒè™‘ã€‚
* ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç»™ Abstract è¿™ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡å®ä¾‹æ·»åŠ æ–°çš„å¯¹è±¡å®šä¹‰ã€‚
*
* ä»javaå»ç†è§£ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯åŠ¨æ€ç»™ä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡åˆ›å»ºå†…éƒ¨ç±»ã€‚
*/
var Abstract = new Object();

/**
* è·å–å‚æ•°å¯¹è±¡çš„æ‰€æœ‰å±æ€§å’Œæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæœ‰ç‚¹è±¡å¤šé‡ç»§æ‰¿ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯è¿™ç§ç»§æ‰¿æ˜¯åŠ¨æ€è·å¾—çš„ã€‚
* å¦‚ï¼š
* var a = new ObjectA(), b = new ObjectB();
* var c = a.extend(b);
* æ­¤æ—¶ c å¯¹è±¡åŒæ—¶æ‹¥æœ‰ a å’Œ b å¯¹è±¡çš„å±æ€§å’Œæ–¹æ³•ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ä¸å¤šé‡ç»§æ‰¿ä¸åŒçš„æ˜¯ï¼Œc instanceof ObjectB å°†è¿”å›falseã€‚
*/
Object.prototype.extend = function(object) {
for (property in object) {
this[property] = object[property];
}
return this;
}

/**
* è¿™ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•å¾ˆæœ‰è¶£ï¼Œå®ƒå°è£…ä¸€ä¸ªjavascriptå‡½æ•°å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œè¿”å›ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°å‡½æ•°å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œæ–°å‡½æ•°å¯¹è±¡çš„ä¸»ä½“å’ŒåŸå¯¹è±¡ç›¸åŒï¼Œä½†æ˜¯bind()æ–¹æ³•å‚æ•°å°†è¢«ç”¨ä½œå½“å‰å¯¹è±¡çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚
* ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´æ–°å‡½æ•°ä¸­çš„ this å¼•ç”¨è¢«æ”¹å˜ä¸ºå‚æ•°æä¾›çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚
* æ¯”å¦‚ï¼š
*
*
* â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦..
*
* é‚£ä¹ˆï¼Œè°ƒç”¨aaa.showValue å°†è¿”å›â€aaaâ€, ä½†è°ƒç”¨aaa.showValue2 å°†è¿”å›â€bbbâ€ã€‚
*
* apply æ˜¯ie5.5åæ‰å‡ºç°çš„æ–°æ–¹æ³•(Netscapeå¥½åƒå¾ˆæ—©å°±æ”¯æŒäº†)ã€‚
* è¯¥æ–¹æ³•æ›´å¤šçš„èµ„æ–™å‚è€ƒMSDN http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/en...jsmthApply.asp
* è¿˜æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª call æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œåº”ç”¨èµ·æ¥å’Œ apply ç±»ä¼¼ã€‚å¯ä»¥ä¸€èµ·ç ”ç©¶ä¸‹ã€‚
*/
Function.prototype.bind = function(object) {
var method = this;
return function() {
method.apply(object, arguments);
}
}

/**
* å’Œbindä¸€æ ·ï¼Œä¸è¿‡è¿™ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•ä¸€èˆ¬ç”¨åšhtmlæ§ä»¶å¯¹è±¡çš„äº‹ä»¶å¤„ç†ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥è¦ä¼ é€’eventå¯¹è±¡
* æ³¨æ„è¿™æ—¶å€™ï¼Œç”¨åˆ°äº† Function.callã€‚å®ƒä¸ Function.apply çš„ä¸åŒå¥½åƒä»…ä»…æ˜¯å¯¹å‚æ•°å½¢å¼çš„å®šä¹‰ã€‚
* å¦‚åŒ java ä¸¤ä¸ªè¿‡è½½çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚
*/
Function.prototype.bindAsEventListener = function(object) {
var method = this;
return function(event) {
method.call(object, event || window.event);
}
}

/**
* å°†æ•´æ•°å½¢å¼RGBé¢œè‰²å€¼è½¬æ¢ä¸ºHEXå½¢å¼
*/
Number.prototype.toColorPart = function() {
var digits = this.toString(16);
if (this < 16) return â€˜0â€™ + digits;
return digits;
}

/**
* å…¸å‹ Ruby é£æ ¼çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå°†å‚æ•°ä¸­çš„æ–¹æ³•é€ä¸ªè°ƒç”¨ï¼Œè¿”å›ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæˆåŠŸæ‰§è¡Œçš„æ–¹æ³•çš„è¿”å›å€¼
*/
var Try = {
these: function() {
var returnValue;

for (var i = 0; i < arguments.length; i++) {
var lambda = arguments[i];
try {
returnValue = lambda();
break;
} catch (e) {}
}

return returnValue;
}
}

/*â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“*/

/**
* ä¸€ä¸ªè®¾è®¡ç²¾å·§çš„å®šæ—¶æ‰§è¡Œå™¨
* é¦–å…ˆç”± Class.create() åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ª PeriodicalExecuter ç±»å‹ï¼Œ
* ç„¶åç”¨å¯¹è±¡ç›´æ¥é‡çš„è¯­æ³•å½¢å¼è®¾ç½®åŸå‹ã€‚
*
* éœ€è¦ç‰¹åˆ«è¯´æ˜çš„æ˜¯ rgisterCallback æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒè°ƒç”¨ä¸Šé¢å®šä¹‰çš„å‡½æ•°åŸå‹æ–¹æ³•bind, å¹¶ä¼ é€’è‡ªå·±ä¸ºå‚æ•°ã€‚
* ä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥è¿™æ ·åšï¼Œæ˜¯å› ä¸º setTimeout é»˜è®¤æ€»ä»¥ window å¯¹è±¡ä¸ºå½“å‰å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœ registerCallback æ–¹æ³•å®šä¹‰å¦‚ä¸‹çš„è¯ï¼š
* registerCallback: function() {
* setTimeout(this.onTimerEvent, this.frequency * 1000);
* }
* é‚£ä¹ˆï¼Œthis.onTimeoutEvent æ–¹æ³•æ‰§è¡Œå¤±è´¥ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒæ— æ³•è®¿é—® this.currentlyExecuting å±æ€§ã€‚
* è€Œä½¿ç”¨äº†bindä»¥åï¼Œè¯¥æ–¹æ³•æ‰èƒ½æ­£ç¡®çš„æ‰¾åˆ°thisï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯PeriodicalExecuterçš„å½“å‰å®ä¾‹ã€‚
*/
var PeriodicalExecuter = Class.create();
PeriodicalExecuter.prototype = {
initialize: function(callback, frequency) {
this.callback = callback;
this.frequency = frequency;
this.currentlyExecuting = false;

this.registerCallback();
},

registerCallback: function() {
setTimeout(this.onTimerEvent.bind(this), this.frequency * 1000);
},

onTimerEvent: function() {
if (!this.currentlyExecuting) {
try {
this.currentlyExecuting = true;
this.callback();
} finally {
this.currentlyExecuting = false;
}
}

this.registerCallback();
}

* åŒæ ·çš„ä¸ onpropertychange äº‹ä»¶ä¹Ÿç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œä¸è¿‡å®ƒåªå…³æ³¨è¡¨å•å…ƒç´ çš„å€¼çš„å˜åŒ–ï¼Œè€Œä¸”æä¾›timeoutçš„æ§åˆ¶ã€‚

* Observer åº”è¯¥å¯ä»¥èƒœä»»åŠ¨æ€æ•°æ®æ ¡éªŒï¼Œæˆ–è€…å¤šä¸ªå…³è”ä¸‹æ‹‰é€‰é¡¹åˆ—è¡¨çš„è¿åŠ¨ç­‰ç­‰
*

/**

/*â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“*/

/**
* åŠ¨æ€æ’å…¥å†…å®¹çš„å®ç°ï¼ŒMSçš„Jscriptå®ç°ä¸­å¯¹è±¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ª insertAdjacentHTML æ–¹æ³•(http: //msdn.microsoft.com/workshop/author/dhtml/reference/methods/insertadjacenthtml.asp)

/**

* ä¸Šæ–‡ä¸­ Abstract.Insertion ç®—æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæŠ½è±¡ç±»ï¼Œå®šä¹‰äº†åä¸ºã€€initializeRange çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæŠ½è±¡æ–¹æ³•
* var Insertion = new Object()ã€€å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªå‘½åç©ºé—´
* Insertion.Before|Top|Bottom|After å°±è±¡æ˜¯å››ä¸ªjavaä¸­çš„å››ä¸ªé™æ€å†…éƒ¨ç±»ï¼Œè€Œå®ƒä»¬åˆ†åˆ«ç»§æ‰¿äºAbstract.Insertionï¼Œå¹¶å®ç°äº†initializeRangeæ–¹æ³•ã€‚

},

});

this.range.setStartAfter(this.element);
},

o Java, no flash. With Mibbit, chatting online is easy, just choose your nickname and press go! No sign-up is required and you can use it from wherever you are with just a web browser.

Connect to IRC networks, IM, twitter, and more coming soon.

Mibbit has many customizable features which can help you make the most of your chat. You can change skins and use real-time language translation, image thumbnails, or even embed Youtube clips and exchange files with other Mibbit users.

function showPulldownMenu() {
try {
if( !(frm=getMainFrame()) ) return;
obj=frm.document.getElementById(â€œMoreServiceâ€);
if(obj) {
var el=document.getElementById(â€œitemTopLeftâ€);
var x=el.offsetLeft;
while (el.offsetParent){
el=el.offsetParent;
x += el.offsetLeft;
}
if(top.frames[1].frames.length>0){
width=170;
strcols = top.frames[1].document.all.tags(â€œFRAMESETâ€)[0].cols;
ss = strcols.split(â€˜,â€™);
width = parseInt(ss[0]);
x=x-width;
}
if (frm.document.documentElement && frm.document.documentElement.scrollLeft) {
obj.style.left=frm.document.documentElement.scrollLeft+x;
} else {
obj.style.left=frm.document.body.scrollLeft+x;
}
if (frm.document.documentElement && frm.document.documentElement.scrollTop) {
obj.style.posTop= frm.document.documentElement.scrollTop;
} else {
obj.style.posTop= frm.document.body.scrollTop;
}
obj.style.visibility=â€™visibleâ€™;
}
} catch(e) {}
}
function hiddenPulldownMenu() {
try {
if( !(frm=getMainFrame()) ) return;
obj=frm.document.getElementById(â€œMoreServiceâ€);
if(obj) {
obj.style.visibility=â€™hiddenâ€™;
}
} catch(e) {}
}

â€™å†å²æ•°æ®åŠ è½½å™¨â€˜è®¾è®¡åŒ…å«ï¼š

Step 1 â€“ åˆ†æåŸå§‹NetSuite Aä¸­çš„äº‹åŠ¡å¤„ç†æ•°æ®ç„¶åå­˜å‚¨åˆ°ä¸¤ä¸ªè‡ªå®šä¹‰è®°å½•ä¸­

Analyze the Transactions of the Source InstanceÂ and Store Results in Two Custom RecordsÂ 

ã€€ã€€æ ¹æ®å®šä¹‰è¦è¿ç§»çš„Transaction Typeï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚ï¼šsales orderï¼Œpurchase orderï¼Œ invoiceï¼Œcredit memoï¼Œvendorbillï¼Œ paymentã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ï¼‰ï¼›è‡ªåŠ¨åˆ†æç°æœ‰Transactionï¼Œæå–æ‰€æœ‰çš„ç³»ç»Ÿå­—æ®µå’Œè‡ªå®šå­—æ®µã€‚

Copy the data of these two Custom Records to the Destination Instance

ã€€ã€€æ ¹æ®åˆ†æå¾—å‡ºçš„è¦è¿å¾™çš„å…·ä½“å­—æ®µä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆå¯èƒ½é€šç”¨äºä¸åŒçš„Transactionç±»å‹ï¼‰ï¼ŒæŠŠåŸå§‹NetSuite Aä¸­çš„æ•°æ®å¯¼å‡ºï¼Œç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªCSVæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­çš„å…·ä½“è¦æ±‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼šå•ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶å¤§å°ä¸è®¸è¶…è¿‡5MBï¼Œå•ä¸ªçš„è¡Œæ•°ä¸è®¸è¶…è¿‡20000è¡Œï¼›è¿™äº›åŸºç¡€çš„è®¾ç½®åœ¨Schedule Scriptä¸­è¿›è¡Œå®šä¹‰ã€‚

Step 3 â€“ åŠ¨æ€ç”Ÿæˆäº‹åŠ¡å¤„ç†æ•°æ®çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªè‡ªå®šä¹‰è®°å½•è¡¨ï¼Œè¯¥è‡ªå®šä¹‰è®°å½•å°†ç”¨äºå­˜å‚¨æ‰€æœ‰çš„å†å²æ•°æ®

Automatically Create the Two New Custom Records which will store All the Transactional Data of the Source System

Step 4 â€“ æ‹·è´ä¼ è¾“åŸå§‹NetSuite Açš„æ•°æ®åˆ°ç›®æ ‡NetSuite Bä¸­

Copy the data from the Source Instance to the Destination Instance

ã€€ã€€ä½¿ç”¨NetSuiteçš„CSVå¯¼å…¥åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œç”¨â€™å†å²æ•°æ®åŠ è½½å™¨â€˜çš„ä»£ç åŠŸèƒ½åŠ¨æ€åŠ è½½åŸå§‹NetSuite Aä¸­Filecabinetçš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œç„¶åPOSTåˆ°ç›®æ ‡NetSuite Bçš„CSV IMPORT queueã€‚

entry.title: Setting up Remote LAN Play for Nintendo Switch Using switch-lan-play (Multi-Switch Remote LAN Party Setup)
entry.content:
Understanding Local Wireless and LAN Play

LAN and Local wireless are different things.

  1. LAN refers to Local Area Network play.
    (Requires connection to a router or mobile hotspotâ€™s WI-FI, displayed as LAN Play in MK8)
  2. Local wireless refers to local wireless play.
    (One device creates a hotspot, others connect to it; does not require connection to a routerâ€™s WIFI; displayed as Wireless Play in MK8)

It involves connecting two or more SWITCH consoles in close proximity over a LAN, or connecting them to the same local network (usually under the same router).

Tutorial: Local Play on Switch - Mario Kart 8 Kitchen Nonsense - Geek Adi - NS LAN Play

How to switch between these modes in MK8?

Nintendo Switch: How to Access LAN PLAY on Mario Kart 8 Deluxe

Press L + R + down on the left joystick simultaneously to switch between these two play modes.

Understanding switch-lan-play

Enjoy games with your friends as if you were on a LAN.

Usage

To play with your friends, both you and your friends need to run the lan-play client connecting to the same Server on your PCs, and set static IP on your Switch.

Your PC and Switch must be connected to the same router.

Visit https://www.lan-play.com/ for instructions on how to set this up. See below for build instructions.

For specific steps: http://www.lan-play.com/install

Whatâ€™s the Use

Remote, remote, remote; internet-based remote play; global internet-based remote play.

Solves online connectivity issues for hacked systems (also supports banned consoles), expands possibilities for more interactive gaming, and allows remote gaming with friends (directly through private servers).

Please use the test server: switch.carlzeng.top:11451

How to Use

1. Switch LAN-Play Server (Remote Server)

Option 1: Use an existing service like lan-play.com

Choose and copy a server address + port from LAN Play Status (format, e.g., joinsg.net:11453)

Option 2: Set up your own server (Instructions provided by the author)

2. Switch LAN-Play Client (Local Network)

(Can be installed on Docker, Windows/Mac, or rooted smartphones):

Docker Client Installation

Mac Client Installation

Client Tools Introduction switch-lan-play

Download the official tool:

  • lan-play-linux (996 KB, Jun 21, 2020)
  • lan-play-macos (927 KB, Jun 21, 2020)
  • lan-play-win64.exe (437 KB, Jun 21, 2020)

PC Installation

If you encounter errors when running on Windows 8, such as â€œwpcap.dll not found, canâ€™t continue executing code, reinstalling the program might solve this problemâ€:

Solution:

Download and install Win10Pcap, Win10Pcap is provided as a Windows Installer module (.msi package).

Alternatively, download from here: https://www.winpcap.org/install/default.htm

3. Switch Settings

WIFI Network Settings on the SWITCH Console

Note: The IP address can be any from 10.13.0.1 to 10.13.255.254, excepting 10.13.37.1. But donâ€™t use the same IP address with your friend.

Please follow the screenshots:

Refer to: http://lan-play.com/install-switch

Installing and Configuring Plugins in Atmosphere on SWITCH (Optional)

ldn_mitm - Download ldn_mitm to play non LAN supported games

How to setup Switch LAN-Play on Android phone/tablet

REQUIRES ROOT and Android 7.0+

Option1: Actions in Android:

  1. Install a latest Termux from f-droid - â€œhttps://f-droid.org/en/packages/com.termux/â€œ
  2. Launch Termux app, youâ€™ll see a black terminal window.
  3. Next, enter these 3 commands one by one:

#(when prompted):choose what version you want to build (choose stable if latest doesnâ€™t compile)

  1. Itâ€™ll setup additional packages and compile lanplay from source (1-5 minutes)
  2. Start WiFi tethering (or connect your phone to wifi)

Option2: Actions in Androidï¼ˆLanPlayAndroidï¼‰:

ä¸‹è½½åœ°å€ï¼šhttps://github.com/liuzhushaonian/LanPlayAndoird/releases

å…ˆç¡®å®šä½ æœ‰Androidç³»ç»Ÿçš„rootæƒé™ï¼Œç„¶åä¸‹è½½LanPlayAndroid

Actions in HOS (Switch):

  1. Connect to WiFi and configure network settings:
  1. download ldn-mitm â€œhttps://github.com/spacemeowx2/ldn_mitm/releases/latestâ€œ
  2. extract it in root of your SDcard (donâ€™t forget to clear the archive bit in Hekate if necessary)
  3. reboot switch

Connect to Servers:

  • Launch Termux and enter bash switchlan, script will ask you for server ip and root privileges
  • or enter bash switchlan server's address to skip asking part, example: bash switchlan edgymin.ga:11451
  • If connection was successful youâ€™ll see â€œServer IP: x.x.x.xâ€ at the end

To Disconnect:

  • Long tap anywhere in Termux -> more -> kill process; or press â€œexitâ€ in Termuxâ€™s notification

How to delete/reinstall lanplay:

enter rm -rf ~/switch-lan-play; rm ~/switchlan in Termux

The process of accessing LAN network multiplayer in the game.

  • The method/process of deploying the client onto an Android smartphone.

    Regarding â€œDomestic Version Gamesâ€: For instance, â€œDomestic Version of Mario Kart 8â€ and â€œInternational Version of Mario Kart 8â€ are not considered the same game and cannot be connected online.

    1. Mario Kart 8: Press left joystick + L + R simultaneously, the fourth option â€œlocal multiplayerâ€ will change to â€œLANâ€, then enter the LAN.
    2. Arms: Local multiplayer, press left joystick + L + R simultaneously to switch to LAN, then enter the LAN.
    3. PokkÃ©n Tournament DX: Supports but havenâ€™t researched LAN path.
    4. Titan Journey: Choose LAN.
    5. Mario Tennis ACE: Free match, local multiplayer, press left joystick + L + R simultaneously to switch to LAN, then enter the LAN.
    6. Splatoon 2 (US version + Japanese version): Press X, choose the fourth option â€œthe shoalâ€, then press left joystick + L + R for 5 seconds, the book in the bottom right corner disappears, the screen changes, and enter the LAN.
    7. Splatoon 3: Press X, choose the fourth option â€œSquid Paradiseâ€, then press L.
    • Please install plugins for Switchâ€™s atmosphere, you can download the latest ldn_mitm here.
    • â€œPrivate Matchâ€ refers to local multiplayer;
    • â€œSALMON RUNâ€ is the local multiplayer â€œsalmon runâ€ (work) mode.
    • For more details, refer to: Splatoon 3 Online Room Hosting Guide

  • https://www.vgtime.com/topic/1179307.jhtml)

Thanks

entry.title: Records of Nintendo Switch Hardware Repair
entry.content:
Records of Hardware Repairs: Emerging from the Software Realm and Taking a Step Towards Hardware Excellence

The Utility

You can gain insights into the hardware aspects of the Nintendo Switch. If interested, you can also engage in hands-on maintenance of your own gaming console, learning about precautions to take during regular usage to prevent/avoid human-induced damages, thereby prolonging the lifespan of these hardware components.

Relevant Content

Pertinent Content

Approach

Case Study - Right Joy-Con Not Charging, LED Off

Observation

The right Joy-Con fails to charge, with its LED inactive. Drawing insights from remote conversations (an almost mystical art, challenging to articulate verbally, perhaps a side effect of prolonged software tinkering, fostering an understanding of the mystical and remote), itâ€™s deduced that the issue likely resides within the right Joy-Con controller, not the consoleâ€™s rails (if multiple right Joy-Con controllers are available, direct substitution for testing can yield more precise diagnostics, pinpointing the issue to the right controller).

Diagnosis

Upon acquiring the malfunctioning controller, observations confirm: pressing buttons yields no response, inserting it into the console prompts an audible system acknowledgment, but the battery indicator shows severe depletion (in red). While the console indicates normal charging for the right controller, the faulty controller remains in a depleted state, incapable of charging.

Disassembling the right Joy-Con, systematic component replacements ensue: battery swap (followed by comprehensive system testing, with the fault persisting), rail replacement (again, with no resolution), disassembling the motherboard, disconnecting all extraneous peripheral cables to isolate other non-essential hardware components (a myriad of them, including joystick cables, ZR cables, rail lights, button cables, rail power and signal cables, motor cables, motor power, and mibo cables, Bluetooth cables), then reassembling with only the motherboard and a functional rail connected to the Switch console for testing, yet the fault remains. A revelation!

Both the rail and its cables are verified new and functional, implicating the motherboard as the likely culprit.

Embarking on chip-level repairs, a realm beyond my realm of expertise and manual dexterity (revealing the precarious nature of hardware endeavors), a flurry of Google tutorials ensue, eventually finding inspiration from videos by â€œYang Geng Papaâ€ and â€œTong Xin Zai Zaiâ€ (coupled with some consultations with my hardware guru, inevitably leading to purchasing a pack of cigarettes for him later). After extensive multimeter measurements, the issue (or at least one of them) is pinpointed to a fuse adjacent to the power socket.

A brief educational aside (knowledge typically acquired in middle or high school physics; a momentary critique of the educational landscape: inundated with knowledge seemingly sufficient for each student to embark on atomic bomb development, yet few are adept at the simple task of repairing household electronic components through basic component replacement and soldering; however, reflecting on obtaining a driverâ€™s license does not guarantee immediate driving proficiency; such is the journey of life, perpetually filled with learning and overcoming challenges): setting the multimeter to the resistance buzz mode (indicating continuity, whereby touching both probes triggers a buzz, signifying a clear path between the probes), no buzz is heard when placed across the fuse in question (its position detailed in the â€œInspiration Sourceâ€ video), whereas the same test on a functional controller elicits a buzz. Eureka!

Resolution

Various repair methods are available, ideally involving fuse replacement on the motherboard (though this entails lengthy procurement and delivery times and significant investment in equipment). Following â€œYang Geng Papaâ€™sâ€ example, bridging the fuse with a soldering iron yields success. Reconnecting to the console, gradually reattaching cables, and retesting restores functionality. Fault resolved.

Another potential issue in series: a faulty charging IC on the motherboard, necessitating microscope and hot air gun interventionâ€¦

Case Study - Pro Controller and Joy-Con Joystick Drift

Observation

The left Joy-Con exhibits joystick drift, manifesting as involuntary character movement during gameplay (an unintended foray into autonomous intelligence), or uncontrollable braking and directional instabilityâ€¦

Diagnosis

Connected to the console, a simple joystick calibration reveals a failure to reset to center, causing the cursor to wander aimlessly.

Resolution

Procuring fourth-generation Joy-Con joysticks and replacing them resolves the issue.

Procuring Pro Controller joysticks, soldering, and replacing the entire joystick assembly; or replacing the worn-out sliding pieces on the joystickâ€™s side with new ones.

Case Study - Joy-Con LED Inactivity

Observation

The SL and SR buttons on the left Joy-Con fail to respond, with their LEDs remaining inactive; they cannot be paired with a new console (yet function normally when connected to an existing console).

Diagnosis/Resolution

Procuring replacement cables for this side prompts an intuitive need for cable replacement. The process is straightforward, as detailed in accessible instructional videos.

â€¦

Case Study - R Key Repair

Observation

The design of the R key (directly soldered onto the right Joy-Con motherboard) and its automated soldering process have long plagued Nintendo with criticism (though it remains a masterpiece balancing price and functionality), with the R key showing no response upon pressing.

The fault divides into two categories: solder pad detachment and intact solder pads, with solder pad detachment being the more common occurrence (owing to the minuscule size of the solder pads).

Diagnosis/Resolution

For intact solder pads, applying some flux and replacing the faulty microswitch resolves the issue.

For detached solder pads, typically, connecting the two pins on the microswitch (the middle pin and any one of the side pins) to specific locations on the motherboard via jumper wires (as evident in the video below, eliminating the need for extensive technical expertise). Caveats and pitfalls include:

  1. Power off and disassemble the Joy-Con motherboard.
    1. Yes, itâ€™s cumbersome but necessary, facilitating ease of operation (given the Joy-Conâ€™s small size) and preventing accidental contact of the soldering iron with the Joy-Conâ€™s plastic casing and other components.
    2. Subsequent testing only requires connecting the rail and battery to directly test the R key repair.
  2. [Optional] Solder a bit of solder onto the middle pin of the microswitch (very fine solder, avoiding short circuits with other pins).
  3. Start by soldering the sides of the microswitch first for stability.
    1. Apply flux before soldering, clean the area around the microswitch on the motherboard, hold the new microswitch in place, and solder.
    2. Note: Avoid allowing solder to touch (connect) the metal dot on the left side of the microswitch, as novices may inadvertently fall into this pitfall (the other side aims for more solder, ensuring a firmer hold), as testing would then reveal all keys malfunctioning.
  4. æ‹¿ç€é£çº¿ï¼Œå…ˆç„Šä¸­é—´é‚£ä¸ªé’ˆè„šï¼Œç„¶åæ˜¯å®ƒæ‰€è¿æ¥çš„â€˜ç¬¬â€™å­—å·¦ä¾§çš„é‡‘å±å°åœ†ç‰‡
    1. æ³¨æ„ï¼šä¸è¦è®©é£çº¿ï¼ˆä¸€èˆ¬æ˜¯éç»ç¼˜çš„ï¼‰è¿æ¥åˆ°å¾®åŠ¨ä¸­é—´é’ˆè„šå’Œè¿™ä¸ªâ€˜ç¬¬â€™å­—å·¦ä¾§çš„é‡‘å±å°åœ†ç‰‡ä¸­é€”è·¯è¿‡çš„é‡‘å±å°åœ†ç‚¹ã€‚å¦åˆ™æµ‹è¯•ä¼šå‘ç°æ‰€æœ‰çš„æŒ‰é”®éƒ½å¤±çµã€‚
  5. æ‹¿ç€ç¬¬äºŒæ ¹é£çº¿ï¼Œæ ¹æ®ç°å®æƒ…å†µï¼Œç„Šä»»æ„ä¸€ä¾§é’ˆè„šåˆ°â€˜ç¬¬â€™å­—ä¸‹æ–¹çš„é‡‘å±å°åœ†ç‚¹
    1. æ³¨æ„ï¼šåŒæ ·ä¸è®©è®©é£çº¿çš„ä¸­é€”ä½ç½®ç¢°è§¦åˆ°å…¶ä»–çš„é‡‘å±å°åœ†ç‚¹ã€‚
  6. ç„Šå¥½ç¡®è®¤å›ºå®šäº†ï¼Œç”¨ä¸‡ç”¨è¡¨çš„æ¥é€šæ€§æµ‹è¯•ï¼ˆä¸¤ç‚¹é—´æ¥é€šçš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ä¼šå‘å‡ºâ€˜å“”â€™éŸ³ï¼‰ï¼›å†è¿æ¥æ»‘è½¨å’Œç”µæ± ï¼Œæµ‹è¯•Ré”®çš„ä¿®å¤æƒ…å†µ
  7. å‡è®¾å„ä¸ªæŒ‰é”®éƒ½éå¸¸å®Œç¾çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œç»™æ–°çš„é£çº¿ä½ç½®ç„Šç‚¹éƒ½æ¶‚ä¸ŠABèƒ¶
    1. è¿™æ ·ç¡®ä¿ç„Šç”µå’Œä¸»æ¿çš„å›ºå®šèƒ½æŒä¹…åŒ–
    2. æˆ‘é‡åˆ°ä¸€ç§æƒ…å†µå› ä¸ºä¸æ‰“èƒ¶å›ºå®šï¼Œå•ç‹¬ä¸»æ¿å’Œæ»‘è½¨ç”µæ± çš„æµ‹è¯•ä¹Ÿokï¼›è€Œæœ€åå…¨éƒ¨ç»„è£…æ‹¼å¥½ä»¥åå°±åˆä¸èƒ½è¯†åˆ«Ré”®äº†ï¼Œåˆå¾—æŒ‰ä¸Šé¢çš„æ­¥éª¤é‡æ–°æ¥è¿‡ã€‚è¶…çº§è€—æ—¶ã€è€ƒéªŒè€å¿ƒå’Œæ³¨æ„åŠ›ã€‚

æœ¬ç« èŠ‚å‚è€ƒ

å‹æƒ…æç¤ºï¼šyoutubeå¦‚æœæ‰“ä¸å¼€ï¼Œè¯·å…ˆæ‰“å¼€ç½‘ç»œåŠ é€Ÿå™¨ï¼Œç„¶åç²˜è´´è¯¦ç»†ç½‘å€åå›è½¦è®¿é—®

Hardware Exploits: Unleashing the Full Potential

Hardware exploits primarily target the following models in descending order of price: OLED version (the latest at the moment), Lite version, extended battery version, and standard version.

Summary of Hardware Exploits (from old to new)

  1. sxcore exploit chip (dated, around 2021 or earlier)
  2. Domestic exploit chips
    1. Without buttons
    2. Label on ribbon cable: (MV1.7.2) Purple LED blinking at startup, then turns green
  3. Raspberry Pi-based exploit chips (featuring golden reset buttons and more)
    1. TFP chip (also known as Raspberry Pi)
    2. Waveshare RP2040 development board
    3. Hwfly Core RP2040
    4. Picofly Core RP2040
    5. Label on ribbon cable: (New 2040plus) Blue LED blinking at startup, then turns green

Sources of Inspiration

entry.title: Nintendo Switch Black Screen Rescue Record
entry.content:
Nintendo Switch Black Screen Rescue

Purpose

To provide some insights on troubleshooting, providing references for similar situations.

Understanding the operation principles of the Atmosphere virtual system, installing new games in the virtual system:

Related

åœ¨çº¿å‡çº§åå¯¼è‡´é»‘å±çš„NS

Current Situation and Diagnosis

  1. Using the new Atmosphere short-circuit tool + injector: Ensure the device is in the shutdown state (long press power button for 12s), then press Vol + Power; this should allow normal access to the Hekate interface.
    • This step lays the foundation for all further actions.
    • The serial number XAJ700â€¦ indicates that itâ€™s a hackable Japanese version console.
  2. Observations:
    • In Hekateâ€™s console info, the fuse count shows 19.
    • Fuse count 19 corresponds to firmware versions 17.0.0 - 18.0.1 (Fuse Reference).
    • The HOS status is reported as â€˜Unknownâ€™.
    • This is an anomaly.
  3. Using a new 17.0.0 SD card; attempting to boot into virtual and real systems:
    • Virtual system: Black screen.
    • Real system: Unknown pkg1 message.

The problem transforms into: How to correctly boot or reinstall HOS into the system?

The suspicion is that the device may have encountered the black screen during an update process (at 6% completion, left unattended, and only noticed later as a black screen).

Attempting to Replace boot0 and boot1 (Unsuccessful)

Firstly, backup the current boot0 and boot1:

  1. Attempt 1: MARIKO 16.0.1 - ERROR
    • Error: Requires ERISTA.
  2. Attempt 2: ERISTA 16.0.1
    • Error: Unknown pkg1 version. Version not supported!
    • Trying to backup bootloaderâ€¦ Found pkg1 (/20230111100014/)

Trying to utilize the latest boot0 and boot1 versions I upgraded:

  • Perform a backup of eMMC BOOT0 & BOOT1 through Hekateâ€™s Tools menu.
  • Copy the backed-up files to the faulty consoleâ€™s SD card in the Restore directory.

Error encountered: pkg2 decryption failed!
pkg1/pkg2 mismatch or old Hekate! Failed to launch HOS!

All known attempts have failed; resorting to restoring the console with the old backup of boot0 and boot1.

å°è¯•2ï¼šERISTA16.0.1

â€‹ é”™è¯¯ï¼Œæç¤ºunknown pkg1 version. How version no supported!

â€‹ Trying backup bootloaderâ€¦ Found pkg1 (/20230111100014/)

å°è¯•ä½¿ç”¨æˆ‘å‡çº§äº†æœ€æ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„boot0 å’Œ boot1:

â€‹ å…ˆå»hekateé‡Œé¢çš„Tools > Backup eMMc > eMMC BOOT0 & BOOT1ï¼Œç„¶åæ‹”å‡ºSDå¡ï¼Œè¿æ¥ç”µè„‘æå–å¤‡ä»½å‡ºæ¥çš„BOOT0 & BOOT1æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚å¤åˆ¶ç²˜è´´åˆ°æ•…éšœæœºå™¨çš„SDå¡ï¼ˆä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ–°å¡ï¼‰çš„å¤‡ä»½æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ä¸‹çš„Restoreæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ä¸­ã€‚

â€‹ é”™è¯¯ï¼Œpkg2 decryption failedï¼

pkg1/pkg2 mismatch or old hekateï¼Failed to launch HOSï¼

æ‰€æœ‰å·²çŸ¥çš„å°è¯•å…¨éƒ¨å¤±è´¥ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ—§çš„å¤‡ä»½èµ·æ¥çš„boot0 å’Œ boot1è¿˜åŸå›å»

Backing up Data from the Old SD Card

Initiating the installation of virtual driversâ€¦

Successfully installed the USB drive using â€˜Driver Geniusâ€™, suggesting an alternative driver tool to use.

Issues related to the Atmosphere (white injector) â€” seems unlikely due to over 19GB Emutendo files.

â€‹ SX OSæ˜¯è£…åœ¨emunandé‡Œçš„

ä¸¤å¹´å‰ï¼šé‡è¦çš„äº‹æƒ…è¯´ä¸‰éï¼ŒSXOSå·²æ­»ï¼SXOSå·²æ­»ï¼SXOSå·²æ­»ï¼

switchå¤§æ°”å±‚è·Ÿsxosçš„åŒºåˆ«

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹2021å¹´çš„æ—¶å€™SX OSçš„SDå¡ç›®å½•ç»“æ„ï¼š

è§£å†³æ­¥éª¤

å¿…é¡»ä½¿ç”¨18.0.1çš„sdå¡ï¼Œæ¥ç”¨hekateå¯åŠ¨ã€‚

é‡æ–°åˆ¶ä½œä¸€ä¸ªemmuc

æ­¥éª¤ï¼šå…ˆè¿›hekateï¼›è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€åˆ‡çš„å¼€å§‹ï¼Œç„¶åç¡®ä¿ä¸»æœºçš„åºåˆ—å·åœ¨å¯è½¯ç ´çš„èŒƒå›´ä¹‹å†…

è¿›hekateåï¼ŒæŸ¥çœ‹ç¡¬ä»¶ä¿¡æ¯ï¼š

è¿™é‡Œé¢æœ‰å¾ˆé‡è¦çš„ç†”æ–­æ•°ä¿¡æ¯å’ŒHOSåŸç‰ˆç³»ç»Ÿå›ºä»¶çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬å·ä¿¡æ¯ç­‰ç­‰ï¼Œå¯¹äºåç»­çš„å¤„ç†æœ‰å¾ˆå¤§å¸®åŠ©ã€‚

18.0.1çš„è™šæ‹Ÿç³»ç»Ÿå®‰è£…æ¸¸æˆæŠ¥é”™

å°è¯•äº†å¾ˆå¤šçš„nspå’Œxciï¼Œæ’é™¤çš„åŸæ–‡æ¡£é”™è¯¯é—®é¢˜ï¼Œæ’é™¤äº†MACç³»ç»Ÿå¤åˆ¶çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚

é™çº§

é™çº§çš„ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æŠŠ17.0.1å’Œ15.0.0çš„ç³»ç»Ÿå›ºä»¶æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹å¤åˆ¶åˆ°SDå¡ä¸­ï¼Œç„¶åç”¨ç›¸å†Œ ã€‹ daybreakæ’ä»¶æ¥å‡çº§ï¼ˆæˆ–è€…é™çº§ï¼‰

è™šæ‹Ÿç³»ç»Ÿå¯ä»¥è¿™æ ·æ“ä½œï¼›åŸç‰ˆ/æ­£ç‰ˆç³»ç»Ÿå› ä¸ºç†”æ–­æ•°é™åˆ¶ä¸èƒ½è¿™æ ·æ“ä½œã€‚

MACç³»ç»Ÿå¤åˆ¶åˆ°SDå¡ä¸Šçš„ç›®å½•ï¼Œä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨æ·»åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªï¼šâ€˜å­˜æ¡£â€™å±æ€§ï¼Œè¿™å°†è®©SWITCHè¯†åˆ«è¿™ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ä¸ºå•ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶è€Œéæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼ˆåœ¨Windowsç”µè„‘ï¼Œå³é”®è¯¥æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼ŒæŸ¥çœ‹å±æ€§åå¾—çŸ¥ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™å¯¼è‡´Daybreakæ’ä»¶æ— æ³•è¯†åˆ«åˆ°è¿™äº›å›ºä»¶çš„æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ã€‚

æ— æ•ˆï¼Œè™šæ‹Ÿç³»ç»Ÿé™ä½åˆ°15.0.0ä»¥åï¼Œå®‰è£…è®¸å¤šæ¸¸æˆä¾ç„¶æŠ¥é”™ï¼ˆåŒæ ·çš„é”™è¯¯ï¼‰ç†”æ–­æ•°é«˜çœŸçš„å¥½å¯æ€•

å‡çº§å¤§æ°”å±‚åˆ°æœ€æ–°æ•´åˆåŒ…

ä½¿ç”¨äº†2024å¹´4æœˆä»½ï¼ˆæˆ–5æœˆä»½ï¼›æ¯”å¦‚æ–‡ä»¶åï¼šâ€NS18.0.1-1.7.0å¤§æ°”å±‚æ•´åˆåŒ….zipâ€ï¼›ä»QQç¾¤æ–‡ä»¶åˆ†äº«ä¸­è·å–ï¼Œå…·ä½“æ–¹æ³•è¯¦è§ï¼šä»»å¤©å ‚Switchå…¨éƒ¨è®°å½•ï¼‰æœ€æ–°å‡ºçš„æ•´åˆåŒ…ï¼Œè§£å†³äº†ç†”æ–­æ•°é«˜çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚

Switching back to Original System + Upgrading to Latest Version 18.0.1

For virtual system, downgrading to 15.0.0, then installing and running â€˜Dave in Deep Watersâ€™ through Daybreak plugin, successful testing.

Ultimately successful: Installed a total of 26 games in the Atmosphere virtual system, including â€˜Overcookedâ€™, â€˜Human Fall Flatâ€™, and â€˜Dave in Deep Watersâ€™.

Cleaning Hidden Mac OS Files and Folders

A quick method using Windows Command Prompt to delete these files in bulk:

This command efficiently deletes these files. In CMD, navigate to the SD card letter (e.g., e:), then run del ._* /a/s to resolve all such files.

Rebuilding the Original Switch System

Rebuilding a pristine official system from scratch is challenging; it must be on version 18.0.1 (due to a fuse count of 19).

Potential resource: Switch Secure System Restoration Guide

Attempting Cross-System Game Migration Copy

In the root directory: emuMMC Â»

SD01 (I have created 2 eMMCs) Â»

Nintendo Â» Contents Â» registered

  1. Attempting to migrate games across systems

First, the original registered directory was backed up, intending to overwrite 134G.

ç»“æœå¤±è´¥äº†ï¼š

eMMCè¿ç§»

å¥½æƒ³ææ¸…æ¥šhekateä¸­çš„eMMC MigrateåŠŸèƒ½ï¼›æˆ‘çš„ç†è§£æ˜¯å®ƒå¯ä»¥å®ç°å°†å…¶ä»–Switchæ¸¸æˆæœº#1SDå¡ä¸­çš„æ¸¸æˆè¿ç§»åˆ°Switchæ¸¸æˆæœº#2çš„SDå¡ä¸­ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå¦‚ä½•åšåˆ°å‘¢ï¼ŸæŠŠæ•´ä¸ªè™šæ‹Ÿç³»ç»Ÿçš„æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹éƒ½æ‹·è´è¿‡å»ï¼Ÿç„¶åè¿™ä¸ªåŠŸèƒ½å°±è¯†åˆ«äº†ï¼›è¯†åˆ«åèƒ½åˆå¹¶å—ï¼Ÿæ¯”å¦‚åŸæ¥çš„Switchæ¸¸æˆæœº#2çš„SDå¡ä¸­æœ‰äº†éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æ¸¸æˆï¼Œèƒ½åˆå¹¶èµ·æ¥ï¼Ÿ

Methods for Utilizing Atmosphere Injector

Methods for Utilizing Atmosphere Injector

Note: This injector is typically unnecessary in daily usage, only required in cases of complete power loss shutdown or forced shutdown (automatically entering the genuine system without games upon reboot without injector).

Switch TX Hardware Hacking Complete Records

TXâ€™s hardware-hacked SX OS (with a red interface) was an option for some endurance machines in 2021.

Here is the process of soldering the TX hardware hacking chip:

  1. How to Solder the TX Chipâ€”Tutorial

  2. Process of the original TX chip hardware hacking (Nv1-6 version): TX Chip Crack Diary for Domestic Switch Hardware Hacking

    1. Inside, thereâ€™s a step: remove the hard drive, then install the hard drive onto the TX cracking chip.

Auxiliary materials:

1. Thermal conductive silicone
2. Insulating tape (yellow)

Switch TX System Transition to Atmosphere

Switch TX System Transition to Atmosphere, Offline System Update, Virtual System Tutorial, Game Installation Tutorial

TX Transition to Atmosphere (Injector Method)

This process, whether upgrading to firmware 13.1, 15.0.1 (injector method), is still secure.

In later usage, upgrades, game installations, etc., various errors may also occur?

If the machine is upgraded in the genuine system (resulting in a fusing count greater than or equal to 15, SXOS will be rendered unusable).

Positive Energy Content Creator Sacrifices Machine for Crack, in Order to Reveal the Anti-Japanese Chip, Everyone Should Not Learn, Support Genuine!

ã€Lingã€‘The Most Convenient Way to Transition from TX to Atmosphere and Back to TX

This provides a tutorial on transitioning from the TX system to Atmosphere, and then back to TX, back and forth.

Inspiration Source

Complete Records of Nintendo Switch

Nintendo Switch Hardware Repair Records

escape() æ–¹æ³•ï¼šé‡‡ç”¨ISO Latinå­—ç¬¦é›†å¯¹æŒ‡å®šçš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰çš„ç©ºæ ¼ç¬¦ã€æ ‡ç‚¹ç¬¦å·ã€ç‰¹æ®Šå­—ç¬¦ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–éASCIIå­—ç¬¦éƒ½å°†è¢«è½¬åŒ–æˆ%xxæ ¼å¼çš„å­—ç¬¦ç¼–ç ï¼ˆxxç­‰äºè¯¥å­—ç¬¦åœ¨å­—ç¬¦é›†è¡¨é‡Œé¢çš„ç¼–ç çš„16è¿›åˆ¶æ•°å­—ï¼‰ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œç©ºæ ¼ç¬¦å¯¹åº”çš„ç¼–ç æ˜¯%20ã€‚unescapeæ–¹æ³•ä¸æ­¤ç›¸åã€‚ä¸ä¼šè¢«æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ç¼–ç çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼š @ * / + è‹±æ–‡è§£é‡Šï¼šMSDN JScript Reference: The escapâ€¦

escape() æ–¹æ³•ï¼šé‡‡ç”¨ISO Latinå­—ç¬¦é›†å¯¹æŒ‡å®šçš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²è¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰çš„ç©ºæ ¼ç¬¦ã€æ ‡ç‚¹ç¬¦å·ã€ç‰¹æ®Šå­—ç¬¦ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–éASCIIå­—ç¬¦éƒ½å°†è¢«è½¬åŒ–æˆ%xxæ ¼å¼çš„å­—ç¬¦ç¼–ç ï¼ˆxxç­‰äºè¯¥å­—ç¬¦åœ¨å­—ç¬¦é›†è¡¨é‡Œé¢çš„ç¼–ç çš„16è¿›åˆ¶æ•°å­—ï¼‰ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œç©ºæ ¼ç¬¦å¯¹åº”çš„ç¼–ç æ˜¯%20ã€‚unescapeæ–¹æ³•ä¸æ­¤ç›¸åã€‚ä¸ä¼šè¢«æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ç¼–ç çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼š @ * / +
è‹±æ–‡è§£é‡Šï¼šMSDN JScript Reference: The escape method returns a string value (in Unicode format) that contains the contents of [the argument]. All spaces, punctuation, accented characters, and any other non-ASCII characters are replaced with %xx encoding, where xx is equivalent to the hexadecimal number representing the character. For example, a space is returned as â€œ%20.â€
Edge Core Javascript Guide: The escape and unescape functions let you encode and decode strings. The escape function returns the hexadecimal encoding of an argument in the ISO Latin character set. The unescape function returns the ASCII string for the specified hexadecimal encoding value.

encodeURI() æ–¹æ³•ï¼šæŠŠURIå­—ç¬¦ä¸²é‡‡ç”¨UTF-8ç¼–ç æ ¼å¼è½¬åŒ–æˆescapeæ ¼å¼çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚ä¸ä¼šè¢«æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ç¼–ç çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼š! @ # $& * ( ) = : / ; ? + â€˜
è‹±æ–‡è§£é‡Šï¼š MSDN JScript Reference: The encodeURI method returns an encoded URI. If you pass the result to decodeURI, the original string is returned. The encodeURI method does not encode the following characters: â€œ:â€, â€œ/â€œ, â€œ;â€, and â€œ?â€. Use encodeURIComponent to encode these characters. Edge Core Javascript Guide: Encodes a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) by replacing each instance of certain characters by one, two, or three escape sequences representing the UTF-8 encoding of the character

encodeURIComponent() æ–¹æ³•ï¼šæŠŠURIå­—ç¬¦ä¸²é‡‡ç”¨UTF-8ç¼–ç æ ¼å¼è½¬åŒ–æˆescapeæ ¼å¼çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚ä¸encodeURI()ç›¸æ¯”ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•å°†å¯¹æ›´å¤šçš„å­—ç¬¦è¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ / ç­‰å­—ç¬¦ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥å¦‚æœå­—ç¬¦ä¸²é‡Œé¢åŒ…å«äº†URIçš„å‡ ä¸ªéƒ¨åˆ†çš„è¯ï¼Œä¸èƒ½ç”¨è¿™ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•æ¥è¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ï¼Œå¦åˆ™ / å­—ç¬¦è¢«ç¼–ç ä¹‹åURLå°†æ˜¾ç¤ºé”™è¯¯ã€‚ä¸ä¼šè¢«æ­¤æ–¹æ³•ç¼–ç çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼š! * ( )
è‹±æ–‡è§£é‡Šï¼š MSDN JScript Reference: The encodeURIComponent method returns an encoded URI. If you pass the result to decodeURIComponent, the original string is returned. Because the encodeURIComponent method encodes all characters, be careful if the string represents a path such as /folder1/folder2/default.html. The slash characters will be encoded and will not be valid if sent as a request to a web server. Use the encodeURI method if the string contains more than a single URI component. Mozilla Developer Core Javascript Guideï¼š Encodes a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) component by replacing each instance of certain characters by one, two, or three escape sequences representing the UTF-8 encoding of the character.

-â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”-

å› æ­¤ï¼Œå¯¹äºä¸­æ–‡å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸å¸Œæœ›æŠŠå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç¼–ç æ ¼å¼è½¬åŒ–æˆUTF-8æ ¼å¼çš„ï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚åŸé¡µé¢å’Œç›®æ ‡é¡µé¢çš„charsetæ˜¯ä¸€è‡´çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼‰ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨escapeã€‚å¦‚æœä½ çš„é¡µé¢æ˜¯GB2312æˆ–è€…å…¶ä»–çš„ç¼–ç ï¼Œè€Œæ¥å—å‚æ•°çš„é¡µé¢æ˜¯UTF-8ç¼–ç çš„ï¼Œå°±è¦é‡‡ç”¨encodeURIæˆ–è€…encodeURIComponentã€‚
å¦å¤–ï¼ŒencodeURI/encodeURIComponentæ˜¯åœ¨javascript1.5ä¹‹åå¼•è¿›çš„ï¼Œescapeåˆ™åœ¨javascript1.0ç‰ˆæœ¬å°±æœ‰ã€‚
è‹±æ–‡æ³¨é‡Šï¼šThe escape() method does not encode the + character which is interpreted as a space on the server side as well as generated by forms with spaces in their fields. Due to this shortcoming, you should avoid use of escape() whenever possible. The best alternative is usually encodeURIComponent().Use of the encodeURI() method is a bit more specialized than escape() in that it encodes for URIs [REF] as opposed to the querystring, which is part of a URL. Use this method when you need to encode a string to be used for any resource that uses URIs and needs certain characters to remain un-encoded. Note that this method does not encode the â€˜ character, as it is a valid character within URIs.Lastly, the encodeURIComponent() method should be used in most cases when encoding a single component of a URI. This method will encode certain chars that would normally be recognized as special chars for URIs so that many components may be included. Note that this method does not encode the â€˜ character, as it is a valid character within URIs.

function genCodeStr(){
var codeRE = new RegExp(â€œâ€˜(.*)â€™ : â€˜(.*)â€™â€,â€giâ€);
var tempStr,codeStr = â€œâ€;
var myReader = new Reader();
myReader.loadFile(â€˜inc/gb2312_utf.txtâ€™);//è¿™é‡Œæ”¹æˆä½ çš„å¯¹ç…§è¡¨å­˜æ”¾çš„è·¯å¾„
while(!myReader.fStream.atEndofLine) {
tempStr = new String(myReader.fStream.readLine());
codeStr += tempStr.replace(codeRE,â€$1â€) + â€œ:â€ + tempStr.replace(codeRE,â€$2â€) + â€œ:â€;
}
Application(â€œcodeDataâ€) = codeStr;
}
function getCodeStr(){
var codeStr = new String(Application(â€œcodeDataâ€));
if(codeStr.indexOf(â€œ%a1%a1â€) == -1){
genCodeStr();
}
return new String(Application(â€œcodeDataâ€));
}
function gb2utf(gbStr){
var codeStr = getCodeStr();
var codeRE = new RegExp(â€œ(%..%..)â€,â€giâ€);
var replaceRE = new RegExp(â€œ(%..%..)â€,â€iâ€);
var gbCode;
var utfCode;
var gbStart;
while((codeRE.lastIndex < gbStr.length) && replaceRE.test(gbStr)){
codeRE.exec(gbStr);
gbCode = new String(RegExp.$1);
gbStart = new Number(codeStr.indexOf(gbCode.toLowerCase()));
var utfStart = 0;
if(gbStart != -1){
utfStart= gbStart + 7;
utfCode = codeStr.substring(utfStart,utfStart + 6);
}else{
utfCode = â€œ%u3000â€;
}
gbStr = gbStr.replace(replaceRE,utfCode);
}
return gbStr;
}

function Reader() { //Class Reader()
this.fso; //Private fso
this.fUri; //Private fUri
this.fStream; //Private fStream
try{
this.fso = new ActiveXObject(â€œScripting.FileSystemObjectâ€);
}catch(exception) {
throw exception;
}
this.loadFile = function(file) { //Public loadFile(file)
this.fUri = Server.mappath(file);
//var fStream = fso.CreateTextFile(tfolder,true,false);
//fStream.WriteLine(â€˜testâ€™);
if(this.fso.fileExists(this.fUri)){
this.fStream = this.fso.openTextFile(this.fUri);
}else{
Response.write(â€˜file dos not existâ€™);
}
}
this.readLineN = function(num) {
var i = 1;
while(i < num && !this.fStream.atEndOfLine) {
this.fStream.skipLine();
i++
}
return this.fStream.readLine();
}
this.closeFile = function() {
fStream.Close();
fso.Close;
}
}

entry.title: Free Trial of Online SuiteCRM Product - Simple Customization or Integration for a Limited Time for Free
entry.content:
Your organization or company needs a CRM system tailored for managing customers or business opportunities effectively.

Introduction, Purpose, and Services

The open-source version of SugarCRM is a lively and easy-to-learn commercial open-source software. SugarCRM Corporation, founded in 2006, has rapidly gained significant influence globally as a customer relationship management software provider.

The Local CX solution aims to meet the needs of rapidly growing small businesses.

Technical Support Services
We are a premium SugarCRM technical support service provider in China, offering development, customization, and other support services to SugarCRM clients. We have skilled experts dedicated to this work.

Proficient CRM Data Migration Capabilities

Data migration involves more than just moving records from one CRM system to another. It is a daunting task that requires proper planning, well-thought-out strategies, and a thorough understanding of the current system. This is crucial to ensure a smooth, rapid, and secure data migration process. Poor data mapping can result in the loss of critical data and key functionalities. Furthermore, it can lead to unexpected impacts on post-migration data and rules. This becomes especially tricky when migrating to an instance used by multiple users (rather than a new instance). Therefore, even when importing thousands of records, care must be taken to ensure each individual record is fully migrated.

Data migration is one of the common requests we receive from clients. Over the years, we have successfully and seamlessly handled multiple SugarCRM migrations from various platforms for clients in different industries. Here are some popular data migration lists we offer to clients from different industries.

  • Migration of data from Excel spreadsheets to Sugar
  • Migration of Salesforce data to SugarCRM
  • SuiteCRM data migration to SugarCRM
  • VtigerCRM data migration to SugarCRM
  • Microsoft Dynamics data migration to SugarCRM
  • Zoho data migration to SugarCRM

CRM Integration with ERP, Data Analysis, and More

Moving data and behaviors from one CRM system to another, such as an ERP or data analysis system.

How to Use

Open the URL in your browser: https://crm.carlzeng.top:3/

Trial username/password: demo/demo

Common Questions about SugarCRM

Questions listed below

Is SugarCRM free?

SugarCRM is an open-source solution, but we provide a free trial to ensure that we can meet all your unique business needs.

Is there free trial software available?

Yes! We offer a 7-day free trial period for clients based on their requirements. If you are interested in SugarCRM, we provide live demos; request a demo here. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions!

What happens after the trial period ends?

At the end of the trial period, we hope you have spent less time on spreadsheets or sorting through vague data and realize the authenticity and usability of Sugar CRM. Sugar CRM sales representatives can assist you in converting the trial version into a production instance. Otherwise, we appreciate you trying our software, and we value your feedback.

Does SugarCRM support multiple languages?

Yes! SugarCRM supports over 30 languages and offers a framework for adding more. As a global CRM, we provide a language pack framework that allows developers to establish support for any language in the display of user interface labels. Access the full language list here. Contact us via phone, email, or chat with us below!

Are there additional costs involved?

Optional products (such as prompts, plugins, LinkedIn Sales Navigator plugin, Oktopost) require additional payments. However, these products can enhance functionality or provide integration with other applications and are not mandatory.

Can I upgrade anytime?

Certainly! Reach out to your sales representative, and they will be happy to assist you!

What are SugarCRM custom field types?

Over the years, we have customized numerous SugarCRM fields for clients. Some of the many possibilities in SugarCRM field customization include phone field customization, custom email fields, autofill through postal codes.

Can relationships be added to â€œcustom SugarCRM fieldsâ€ to automatically update one fieldâ€™s value by changing another fieldâ€™s value?

Yes, indeed. It is possible to automatically update one fieldâ€™s value by changing another fieldâ€™s value through SugarCRM customization.

How to manually create custom fields in SugarCRM?

There are several convenient ways to create custom fields in SugarCRM. You can use Sugar Studio to create basic custom SugarCRM fields without writing any code, or you can contact certified SugarCRM partner organizations (such as TMC) for advanced customization based on your unique requirements.

What is Sugar Studio?

Sugar Studio is a tool in SugarCRM that allows users to add basic customizations to fields and can also change the appearance of modules.

How to access Sugar Studio in SugarCRM?

Sugar Studio is located on the administration homepage. Only users with administrator privileges can access it.

What is the purpose of having custom SugarCRM fields?

The default version of Sugar has only a few modules with default fields, including Marketing, Sales, and Support modules. However, in its default form, Sugar may not be useful for most businesses as each business has its unique processes and entities. Hence, it is common practice to add custom fields and modules and remove current fields and modules that are not necessarily relevant to the businessâ€™s CRM implementation.

Can validation be set for SugarCRM custom fields to automatically update one fieldâ€™s value by changing another fieldâ€™s value?

Yes, you can update one fieldâ€™s value by changing another fieldâ€™s value. This can be achieved through SugarCRM customization.

How to delete any unnecessary custom fields in SugarCRM?

If you do not have any coding knowledge, you can use Sugar Studio to delete any unnecessary custom fields.
Furthermore, you can also contact SugarCRM experts like TMC, who can complete the task for you through code.

Self-Deployment

docker-compose.yml

Uses the shared network template_default and a MariaDB database. Refer to: Sharing a single MariaDB (Docker Database Service) among multiple Docker containers.

Installation of Chinese Language Pack

Download link for Chinese Language Pack

Steps: Select â€œadmin,â€ scroll down, find the â€œModule Loaderâ€ item under Developer Tools, upload the downloaded localization package, click on â€œINSTALLâ€ that appears after downloading in that item to complete the installation. Then navigate to the admin interface, select the Simplified Chinese language from the local entries under the system dropdown list, and save. Reopen the systemâ€™s URL link and choose Simplified Chinese.

Sources of Inspiration

bitnami/suitecrm

SugarCRM Product Feature Demo - SugarCRM Demo Trial

LouisheCOM - Free International Open Source Software SuiteCRM Service Provider

jontitmus-code/SuiteCRM8_dockerhttps://tmcsys.cn/dev-suitecrm-ui.html)

-â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

function hideAlertBox(elemId)
{
document.getElementById(elemId).style.display=â€™noneâ€™;
}

function getAlertBoxHtml(sTitle, sMessage, iType, width, helpUrl, helpText)
{
if (iType != NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOWEST_PRIORITY &&
iType != NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOW_PRIORITY &&
iType != NLAlertDialog.TYPE_MEDIUM_PRIORITY &&
iType != NLAlertDialog.TYPE_HIGH_PRIORITY)
iType = NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOW_PRIORITY;
if(!width)
width = 600;
if (!sTitle)
{
switch (iType)
{
case NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOWEST_PRIORITY:
sTitle = â€œConfirmationâ€;
break;
case NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOW_PRIORITY:
sTitle = â€œInformationâ€;
break;
case NLAlertDialog.TYPE_MEDIUM_PRIORITY:
sTitle = â€œWARNINGâ€;
break;
case NLAlertDialog.TYPE_HIGH_PRIORITY:
default:
sTitle = â€œErrorâ€;
break;
}
}

var bHelpLink = false;
if (helpUrl && helpUrl.length > 0)
{
bHelpLink = true;
if (!helpText)
helpText = â€œVisit this Help Topicâ€;
}
return â€œ

<a href=\â€œâ€ + helpUrl.replace(/â€œ/g, â€œ&#34â€) + â€œ\â€œ>â€ + helpText + â€œ

â€œ
â€œ;
}

NLAlertDialog = Class.create();

NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOWEST_PRIORITY = 0;
NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOW_PRIORITY = 1;
NLAlertDialog.TYPE_MEDIUM_PRIORITY = 2;
NLAlertDialog.TYPE_HIGH_PRIORITY = 3;

NLAlertDialog.prototype =
{
initialize: function(sId)
{
this.sId = sId || â€œNLAlertDialogâ€;
},

show: function(sTitle, sMessage, iType, sTargetDivId)
{
var posX = document.body.clientWidth / 2;
var posY = document.body.clientHeight / 2;

var sTitleId = this.sId + â€˜_titleâ€™;
var sMessageId = this.sId + â€˜_messageâ€™;

if(!iType) iType = NLAlertDialog.TYPE_LOW_PRIORITY;

if (!this.hndDialogDiv)
{
this.hndDialogDiv = document.createElement(â€œdivâ€);
this.hndDialogDiv.innerHTML = getAlertBoxHtml(sTitle, sMessage, iType);
this.hndDialogDiv.style.display = â€œnoneâ€;
this.hndDialogDiv.style.position = â€œabsoluteâ€;
document.body.appendChild(this.hndDialogDiv);
}
if (sTargetDivId != null)
{
$(sTargetDivId).innerHTML = this.hndDialogDiv.innerHTML;
return;
}
if (this.hndDialogDiv.style.display == â€œblockâ€)
return;
this.hndDialogDiv.style.display = â€œblockâ€;
this.hndDialogDiv.style.top = posY - (this.hndDialogDiv.clientHeight / 2);
this.hndDialogDiv.style.left = posX - (this.hndDialogDiv.clientWidth / 2);
},

hide: function( sTargetDivId )
{
if (sTargetDivId != null)
$(sTargetDivId).innerHTML = â€œâ€;
else if (this.hndDialogDiv != null)
this.hndDialogDiv.style.display = â€œnoneâ€;
}
}

entry.title: Accelerating Docker Pull or Docker-compose Pulling Images - GitHub Source
entry.content:
Augmenting Speed for GitHub Docker Sources

Downloading zlib (from GitHub) is quite laborious, as the speed is exceptionally slow.

I came across a remarkable article: Speeding up Docker Pull

Its Purpose

To accelerate GitHubâ€™s docker sources, for instance:

ghcr.io/zlib-searcher/zlib-searcher:latest

ghcr.io/puzzithinker/zlib-searcher:master

How to Use

  1. Configuring http-proxy.conf
  1. Configuring https-proxy.conf

  1. Restarting the Service

  2. Monitoring to Ensure the Proxy Settings are Operative

Related Content

Source of Inspiration

https://zu1k.com/posts/coding/speedup-docker-pull/#Setting-up-a-proxy-for-docker

If the Docker repository for the image source is deleted

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23935141/how-to-copy-docker-images-from-one-host-to-another-without-using-a-repository

entry.title: Improving Artalk Comments to Version 2.8.3 and Resolving Error (Request Response 404)
entry.content:
Updating Artalk comments to version 2.8.3 and addressing the Artalk Error: Request Response 404, which prevented fetching the comment list data.

Purpose

Upgrading Artalk comments to version 2.8.3.

Resolving Artalk Error: Request Response 404, which hindered fetching the comment list data.

Related

Journey

Artalkâ€™s SMTP configuration has consistently failed to send emails. The root cause remains unclear. Is it due to certificates or lack of logs? How can validation be bypassed? Hence, the immediate step is to attempt an upgrade. The current version in Docker output is:

Ref: Artalk Issue #748

The decision is made to upgrade Artalk to the latest version available!

Upgrade Steps:

With these commands, Artalk is upgraded to the latest version: Artalk (v2.8.3/8af7136)

However, upon upgrading, an error is encountered: Request Response 404.

Artalk Error: Request Response 404 - Unable to fetch comment list data.
Click to retry | Open console

Solution:

After thorough checks and testing, itâ€™s confirmed that Docker startup is functioning normally.

Thereâ€™s a strong suspicion that the error stems from an outdated Hexo version, leading to page request errors.

The problem transforms into: how to upgrade Hexo?

Upon review the next day, itâ€™s concluded that the server-side Artalk has been reinstalled with the latest version (while retaining the original data). Therefore, the issue likely lies in integrating with Hexo. Itâ€™s essentially a matter of Node installation on the server, Hexo-related configurations, and the JS client, each of which is examined:

Attempting to update the Hexo Artalk plugin:

By chance, notice that the _config.yml file in Hexo references a specific version of Artalk (an older version):

Itâ€™s imperative to update these references to the latest version pulled via docker-compose:

Utilizing cdnjs

After modifying the _config.yml file in Hexo to reference the latest version of Artalk for both JS and CSS, and leveraging cdnjs, the following steps are executed:

The 404 error is successfully resolved.

Next Step: Continue investigating and testing Artalk V2.8.3â€™s SMTP notification sending functionality.

ERROR Email: Email sending failed via SMTP tls: failed to verify certificate: x509: certificate relies on legacy Common Name field, use SANs instead

Even when changing the SMTP port to 25, the error persists:

The suspicion grows: the next issue to tackle is the artalk | FATAL tls: provide a valid cert or key path.

Release Notes

Ensure that the modifications made to the JS and CSS files in the _config.yml are synced to the English version of the site under the /en directory. Otherwise, the comment functionality in the English version might also encounter the Error: Request Response 404.

Sources of Inspiration

[Customizing Hexo for Broad Artalk Deployment](
